Gordon Glimpses
It was the week of the remarkable solo performance.
Seemingly without the knowledge of anybody, President
Gordon grasped the Student Council's one professor-one
course proposal and thrust it upon two unwary N-L
reporters like his own brainstorm. At the same time, the
President in effect announced his determination to build
up the Evening College come hell or high water, a move
that undoubtedly will prompt even more faculty
mistrust about his administrative wisdom.
On the first point, we praise Gordon's overall pledge to
improve undergraduate education. We also hope that he
truly means it, and is not just using the issue as a
political football against the faculty. The next step is for
the Academic Council next Wednesday to admit that
undergrad education is currently inadequate, and begin
to establish means to redress many educational
grievances.
In principle we support the Student Council's
insistence that more courses and seminars be taught,
though we think that a uniform rule of one professor-one
course may be too rigid.
But the President is treading on precarious waters
with his Evening School proposal. During these hard
financial times, when the school is millions in the red,
Gordon is working with the Evening College Dean to
expand its full-time teaching staff from zero to fifteen by
1975. The Evening College has no endowment, but
Gordon is gambling on increased enrollment to pay the
faculty bill. So far he has not substantiated his claim
that more professors necessarily mean more money.
And without a money reserve and with the nation-wide
university slump, these professors could be like the
"Homewood 23.": Social Relations and Biology
professors that in two years will drain $500,000 annually
from University coffers after their foundation grants
expire.
It is not the fault of these professors that Hopkins is
losing money. It is a lack of foresight on the part of the
administration and Academic Council. The University
cannot afford to be bulldozed into another dubious
expansion without careful discussion.

Levering Lassoed
Although final budget figures are by no means in, all
indicators point to a cutback in Levering Hall's already
tight operation. Levering sponsors a host of the most
worthwhile operations at Hopkins, in terms of value to
both students and the city.
Yet annually Chaplain Wickwire and the Student
Association have to fight for every penny. There seem to
be certain incongruities in the University's approach.
First, why do the University books show that Levering
receives its full appropriation of $89,000 from Hopkins
when, in fact, much of that revenue is self-generated?
Second, does it make any sense to split supervision of
Levering, giving programs to Central Administration
and budget to Arts and Sciences? Third, why has
Levering been ignored by the Hopkins Fund in its search
for foundation grant's'? And fourth, how does the
University come up with its figure that Levering's
budget has increased 234 per cent in the last three
years? The other points are debatable. This one is just
wrong.
Why not put budget and programs under one roof--the
Central Administration, as the Levering Advisory
Board has urged. For one thing, this would mean that
the entire University, instead of just Homewood, would
be taxed to supply the Levering subsidy. The position
that Levering's programs effect only Arts and Sciences
is untenable.
Levering is one of the few operations at this
University that cannot be cut.

It was the week of the remarkable solo performance.

President in effect announced his determination to build
up the Evening College come hell or high water, a move

mistrust about his administrative wisdom.
On the first point, we praise Gordon's overall pledge to
improve undergraduate education. We also hope that he
truly means it, and is not just using the issue as a
political football against the faculty. The next step is for
the Academic Council next Wednesday to admit that
undergrad education is currently inadequate, and begin
to establish means to redress many educational
grievances.
In principle we support the Student Council's
insistence that more courses and seminars be taught,
though we think that a uniform rule of one professor-one
course may be too rigid.
But the President is treading on precarious waters
with his Evening School proposal. During these hard
financial times, when the school is millions in the red,
Gordon is working with the Evening College Dean to
expand its full-time teaching staff from zero to fifteen by
1975. The Evening College has no endowment, but
Gordon is gambling on increased enrollment to pay the
faculty bill. So far he has not substantiated his claim
that more professors necessarily mean more money.
And without a money reserve and with the nation-wide
university slump, these professors could be like the
"Homewood 23.": Social Relations and Biology
professors that in two years will drain $500,000 annually
from University coffers after their foundation grants
expire.
It is not the fault of these professors that Hopkins is
losing money. It is a lack of foresight on the part of the
administration and Academic Council. The University
cannot afford to be bulldozed into another dubious
expansion without careful discussion.

indicators point to a cutback in Levering Hall's already

University come up with its figure that Levering's

The Baltimore City Police Department has

abortive drug raid on an East Baltimore
community center.
On the evening of February 19, after a
week of surveillance, ten members of the
police narcotics unit forcibly entered the
three-story rowhouse in the 2100 block East
Baltimore Street with a search and seizure
warrant for "dangerous substances and
paraphernalia."
According to Jody Landers, 17, owner of
the house, police smashed in back doors on
the first and second floors and the first floor
front door with sledge hammers.
Detective Sgt. William Kearney, who led
the raid, denied that police caused damage
to the house besides smashing in the first
floor doors. He added that the doors were
forced "to prevent the destruction of
evidence."
Police spent two hours in the community
center but found no drugs and made no
arrests. They confiscated a telephone
extension, a belt (described as a possible
drug tourniquet), half a souvenir Indian
Pipe, and a blank gun.

room," said Allen Holt, 19, one of five

look at the sign on the front door that warns
people not to bring in any dope.

whom were dressed in "mod attire," were

throwing them against a wall and searching
them.
Landers' brother Mike, who does not live

in progress. A police officer told him to
"come on down and bring some tea". Mike

tea bags.

\mouth and could be shot without too much
